/COMMIT_MSG.message:
So here is the fundamental issue. The port's pxe_enabled is intended to be set by administrators to be authoritative for their environment. I.e. I know I've patched port 1 and port 2 to the provisioning network or switch, and I only want those to PXE, so I'll set them appropriately from ironic which should be the authoritative source of truth. Based upon that value is how templates are written, port configurations are chosen, and ultimately what port(s) are used in provisioning port binding.

Your commit message is your making the individual piece of hardware authoritative, which is really a feature and one that doesn't align with the overall interaction of the pxe_enabled field for operators, and doesn't exactly qualify as a stable backport as a bug fix. Granted, it may be nice to know from introspection what ports were pxe enabled, but again such behavior is a feature.

Hey Julia, while this may look like a new feature, it is actually a fix for a bug that has a long history: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1395819
TLDR: If pxe_enabled is not set, then nodes can fail to PXE boot during deployment.  This is an exceptionally bad user experience in a tripleo environment, where a deployment could take a couple hours to fail.

And to make things more confusing for the user, when in-band introspection is used, pxe_enabled is automatically correctly set on the ports and everything works perfectly (at least with OSP13).  This fix modifies iDRAC OOB introspection to behave the same way that IB introspection does in regards to setting pxe_enabled.

I agree that Ironic should be the authoritative source for setting pxe_enabled.  That said, I think it's a good thing for introspection (IB or OOB) to discover the current PXE configuration.  This makes it visible to the user and if they want to change it, then they can certainly do that.

Maybe an update to the commit comment would help?

glossary/locale/ru/LC_MESSAGES/glossary..message: Maybe better "механизм распространения уровня L2"? We're talking about dynamic L2 connection between hosts containing instances connected to one virtual network

I was just following pattern here for other services which were in plural ("сервис блочных хранилищ" L59, "сервис вычислительных ресурсов" L87, ). Let me know if we would prefer to have everything in singular, and let me know if first word "Сервис" in all of them should start with Capital letter.

No, there is a term for sharding - сегментирование.

[0] https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Секционирование (inside article)

[1] https://www.insight-it.ru/theory/2008/segmentirovanie-bazy-dannykh/

[2] https://books.google.sk/books?id=jABUAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA270&lpg=PA270&dq=сегментирование+базы+данных&source=bl&ots=f5JwndCTyo&sig=ACfU3U2ND5sKx8w_8ZLlEX7izUVdArhNdA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiP0J7F-O_jAhVPJlAKHebtApc4ChDoATAQegQICRAB#v=onepage&q=сегментирование%20базы%20данных&f=false

The context here is not clear, but since we often translate "public network" and "private network" as "публичная сеть" and "приватная сеть", then the verb form to make network public would be "опубликовать". I'm open to change, if we have good examples in existing translations.

test/functional/test_slo.py.message: Should maybe go elsewhere; I know test_symlink (at least) could benefit from this.

itertools.groupby() is going to preserve byte ordering for us:

 >>> group_file_contents(b'xyzzx')
 [(b'x', 1), (b'y', 1), (b'z', 2), (b'x', 1)]

Maybe I shoulda named it run_length_encoding or similar? *shrug*

(FWIW, for the longest time I'd get confused and expect groupby to have an implied sort in there.)

Maybe I'm out to lunch here, but I found a different reason not to like this. In the original code, tests were for specific locations in the buffer, like 1024*1024-1 and so on. The new test only counts, but does not care if any chunks were swapped around... e.g. imagine fragment 0 in position 1 and fragment 1 in position 0. Of course this is extremely unlikely, unless someone tries to read from 2 object servers in parallel and then completions race somehow. But still, I feel like we're letting entropy in.
You can see it in action with tests like this.

swift/common/middleware/slo.py.message: I hit this constraint even we accept the bulk can take infinite objects to delete. That is because we call this method before feeding the listing result to the Bulk middleware, isn't it?

I wonder if it'd be worth keeping *some* limitation, just to guard against someone trying OOM-kill the proxy by uploading a manifest with 1,000 segments, then another manifest that references *that* manifest 1,000 times...

Something like

 curl -v http://saio:8090/v1/AUTH_test/c/o -X PUT -d 'o'
 curl -v http://saio:8090/v1/AUTH_test/c/o2?multipart-manifest=put -X PUT -d "$(python -c 'import json; print(json.dumps([{"path": "c/o"}] * 1000))')"
 curl -v http://saio:8090/v1/AUTH_test/c/o3?multipart-manifest=put -X PUT -d "$(python -c 'import json; print(json.dumps([{"path": "c/o2"}] * 1000))')"
 curl -v http://saio:8090/v1/AUTH_test/c/o3?multipart-manifest=delete -X DELETE

will fail that DELETE on master... and if I take out this check, it'll succeed (Eventually, I guess? It's been running a few minutes now...) but make my proxy-server process consume ~1.2G of memory for the duration. Pretty sure just one extra layer will get me an OOM-kill.

Maybe we could compare against 10x max_manifest_segments or something instead?

nova/test.py.message: Any chance we could just encode the three parameters instead?

That seems slightly worse to me.  I assume you're not proposing to make them positional *and* mandatory, since then callers would have to write horrible stuff like:

    self.assertXmlEqual(expected, observed, False, False, False)

I expect you're suggesting they'd be positional and optional, in which case callers would have to write

    self.assertXmlEqual(expected, observed, some_option=True)

which is exactly what the **options way already supports.  But the **options way avoids violating DRY since options can be added just by adding them to XMLMatches, without having to duplicate them here as well.  It also avoids a bulky parameter list which could grow even longer in the future.

OTOH, making them optional parameters provides validation against typos in the option names, but that could equally be achieved with checks in XMLMatches if we were really worried about it.

Swings and roundabouts, I guess ...

nodepool/zk.py.message:
We have to be careful with this since it's basically a change in functionality. Before, the error would propagate up to the caller of deleteNode(). Now it's hidden and we don't know if the delete is successful or not. For example, the call in NodeDeleter.delete() will immediately call manager.nodeDeletedNotification() after deleteNode() if it was successful. There's no way to tell if the node was actually deleted or not, so the notification may cause new failures if the node still exists.

One way I can think of dealing with this is having deleteNode() return True/False on success/failure, then calls to deleteNode() can check the return value.

doc/source/specs/2019.11/approved/stx-mo.message: I would expand this statement to indicate that collection, monitoring and analysis is required across the infrastructure, cluster and application.

Can we elaborate on the off-box deployment?  Indicating that the collection components would still need to be deployed on the system, but the storage and visualization components would be made optional.
I would also mention that the existing collectd custom metrics and monitoring data will be integrated with Elasticsearch.  This would supplant the current storage in InfluxDB.
Logstash is likely required for providing the off-box data streams and the integration of collectd metrics.
I would also state that the defaults can be overridden using user Helm overrides during stx-monitor deployment.
added statement for defaults can be overridden via user helm overrides

I would just reference the current release since 7.1 is likely not the release version that will be integrated.

eg. https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/index.html
What's the License and can it be combined with the Apache-2.0 license?  What happens if someone wants to commercialize StarlingX with the Elastic License?

Elastic (elastic.co) has different licensing requirements depending on what components are being deployed and what variant of the pre-built software is being used.  The Elastic monitoring is an optional service, but if a company wanted to commercialize with Elastic in the offer, they would need to enter into an OEM agreement with Elastic.  Here is some background information and the licensing agreement information from Elastic.


Elastic Subscription Models:
https://www.elastic.co/subscriptions
 
Elastic Elasticsearch License (typically just referred to as the Elastic License):
https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/master/licenses/ELASTIC-LICENSE.txt
 
Elastic OEM License and Support Agreement:
https://www.elastic.co/agreements/inc/oem

Elastic End User License Agreement:
https://www.elastic.co/eula

If only the "OSS" builds are used (or the x-pack directory is deleted from the source trees prior to building) then the result should fall entirely under the Apache License v2 (according to the notices in the repositories I checked anyway). I don't know whether the result would be suitable for these purposes however, particularly as things like the logstash plugin are in the Elasticsearch x-pack. Depending on your timeline, https://opendistro.github.io/for-elasticsearch/ might make this easier.

I would caution against incorporating an actual distribution of Elastic License software within StarlingX itself. By doing so you're basically telling the users of your distribution that they're receiving a mixed bag of software only some of which is free/libre open source, so even if their legal department/counsel is okay with the general terms of any OSI-approved license they still now end up needing to inspect the licenses of every component you ship for indication as to what they can safely use in their deployments. This is a significant and costly barrier for many organizations, and is just as likely to cause them to rule out your software entirely rather than deal with the extra legal hassles.

specs/2019.03/approved/build-2006166-lay.message: Does this layered builds work item include the "filter" files  in metal?

I think what you're asking here is for the filter files to be broken up and scattered like the image.inc files. We can look at doing this, certainly, to have the filter files coresident with the image.inc files.

Originally, the package lists were contained in the kickstarts, so having the filters and the script that processed them live with the kickstarts made sense. The package lists are now separate, so I think it probably makes sense to move the generation tool to stx-root and we could break up the filter files at that point.

Note that the image.inc files will only now be in the "flock" layer, as this is where the ISO is built. The packages pulled in from other layers will be included in the central image.inc, or a new layer-specific image.inc added. If the filter files are broken out, there will need to also be a central filter file.

I don't understand why this change makes sense. Before, we were saying "we know we registered rp_uuid in parent_uuid_by_rp_uuid; if its value is None it means rp_uuid represents a root provider". Now we're saying "we might have neglected to register rp_uuid; but if so, it's a root, promise".

Under what circumstances could we have neglected to register rp_uuid? And why is that okay?

[Later] Okay, I think I see. Now we're building parent_uuid_by_rp_uuid only based on the psums related to the ARRs under consideration. Whereas before we were building it based on *all* psums for all providers in the world.

Which means we have a bug. Because as written this will only work as long as we always have resources from at least one provider at most one level down from the root. Looklook:

          root
            |
          child
            |
        grandchild

Right now we're relying on there being an ARR for `root` (parent_uuid_by_rp_uuid[root] will be present, and None) or `child` (parent_uuid_by_rp_uuid[child] will be present, and point to `root`, but `root`  will be absent, but we're assuming its parent is None, which happens to be true).

But if we had no ARR for `root` or `child`, then we would look for `grandchild`'s parent, which would be absent, and assume *its* parent is None, i.e. that `child` is a root, which it's not.

So

What we need is a test case where resources (and... traits?) are only requested starting at the third tier, and such that the same_subtree algorithm should produce different results if we're only considering the subtree starting at `child` as "the whole tree".

Whether we do it like this or with a single same_subtree, I don't see how cn1 gets to be in any result, ever. The parents & grandparent are the only common ancestors of {NUMA1, the NICs, the PFs}. So that should fail our definition of same_subtree no matter what.

As I said the other day when you asked, I think overlapping same_subtreeZ should behave the same as their union. So I think you've just proven that that's not the case, but you've shown that it's a bug rather than me interpreting things wrong. (I still may be interpreting things wrong, but there's definitely a bug.)

[Later]

Okay, I started dumping stuff, and we blow out to 12 *not* because numa1/cn1 ever gets involved (phew).

It *is* because my intuition was wrong about overlapping same_subtreeZ.

When we say same_subtree=COMPUTE,NIC,PORT, the COMPUTE gets to act as the sub-root for that subtree, so we allow combinations where PFs aren't under their respective NICs. Whereas when we have same_subtree=NIC,PORT separate, it forces all NICs and PORTs to be anchored at the NIC.

The results are below. VCPU always comes from CN2. The * ones are the extra ones we get when we combine into one same_subtree.

   nic1, pf1_1
 * nic1, pf2_1
 * nic1, pf2_3
 * nic1, pf3_1
 * nic2, pf1_1
   nic2, pf2_1
   nic2, pf2_3
 * nic2, pf3_1
 * nic3, pf1_1
 * nic3, pf2_1
 * nic3, pf2_3
   nic3, pf3_1

This is worth having a test case for. However, it doesn't need the deep fixture, so I'll throw up a patch that puts it in with the regular same_subtree tests.

* the 12 one, for the reasons you describe
* a something like 36 one, when _COMPUTE is not in same_subtree (I can't remember the details and at this point is doesn't matter)

As Eric mentioned in a top-level comment, why don't we lock on the instance.uuid in this method so we can lock against a race with the sync task running at the same time as we're processing the event? Note that stop_instance already locks on instance.uuid but start_instance doesn't. I'm not sure if start_instance needs to worry about a lock or not, the power state sync task will only stop an instance, never start it.

The scenario I'm thinking is something like:

t0: we get the event and pass the api checks for vm/task/power state

t1: the sync task starts running before the instance.task_state is set by the api and it calls api.stop_instance

t2: the compute gets the event and starts processing it

t3. the compute stops the instance and clears the task_state while the t2 thread is processing it in the driver

I think either way one of those is going to lose the race and the instance.save() will likely fail with UnexpectedTaskStateError so maybe the lock is not a major concern.
If we decide not to lock, I'm thinking we should have a code comment summarizing the above, just to show we've thought it through and accepted the risk.

I know that we talked about this before, but if we're getting a power-update event for an instance on a Stein compute, the API will set the task_state on the instance and cast off to the old compute service which won't do anything with the event but the instance's task_state will be stuck and the admin will have to reset the state using the os-resetState API. That's not so great, especially considering we've always told deployers that you must upgrade ironic before nova (though ironic won't be able to send the even until the nova API service is upgraded to expose the microversion, but still, we could have old compute services during a rolling upgrade). If we aren't going to have compute service version checking in the API, let's be sure to mention something in the release note that this won't work for instances running on older compute services during a rolling upgrade.

Should that caveat also be in the doc for the conf opt on the ironic side?

Now that the API is no longer setting the task_state I think this is less of a concern. The only "bad" thing that could happen now is if ironic sends the event for an instance on an old compute, the API creates an action record, but casts to a Stein compute that doesn't "complete" the action, meaning doesn't hit anything with a @wrap_instance_event decorator to record a start/finish event on the action, but the worst that happens with that is you've got a stop/start action in the API with no events under it. So you can leave this if you want, but it's less of a concern than leaving an instance stuck with a task_state that the admin has to reset.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Right, and the latter condition includes the former.

Condition1:

    same_subtree=A,B&same_subtree=B,C
  = (A is B’s ancestor or B is A’s ancestor) and
    (B is C’s ancestor or C is B’s ancestor)
  = (A is B’s ancestor and B is C’s ancestor) or
    (B is A’s ancestor and B is C’s ancestor) or
    (A is B’s ancestor and C is B’s ancestor) or
    (B is A’s ancestor and C is B’s ancestor)
  = (A,B,C are in the same path in this order) or
    (B is an ancestor of both A and C) or
    (B is a descendant of both A and C) or  <- Note that this can be split into 2 cases if multiple parenting is not allowed
    (C,B,A are in the same path in this order)
  = (A,B,C are in the same path in this order) or
    (B is an ancestor of both A and C) or
    (C,A,B are in the same path in this order) or  <- these two...
    (A,C,B are in the same path in this order) or  <-     ...are split ones
    (C,B,A are in the same path in this order)
  = (A,B,C are in the same path in this order) or  <- these two...
    (A,C,B are in the same path in this order) or         ...can be combined into one
    (C,B,A are in the same path in this order) or  <- so do...
    (C,A,B are in the same path in this order) or         ...these two
    (B is an ancestor of both A and C)
  = (A,B,C are in the same path and the top is A) or ... 1-1
    (A,B,C are in the same path and the top is C) or ... 1-2
    (B is an ancestor of both A and C)               ... 1-3

Condition2:

    same_subtree=A,B,C
  = (A is an ancestor of both B and C) or  ... 2-1
    (B is an ancestor of both C and A) or  ... 2-2
    (C is an ancestor of both A and B)     ... 2-3

Since (1-1 < 2-1) and (1-2 < 2-3) and (1-3 = 2-2), "Condition 2" includes "Condition 1".

The difference is:

    ((2-1) - (1-1)) + ((2-3) - (1-2))
  = (A is an ancestor of B and C, but B and C are not in the same path) or
    (C is an ancestor of A and B, but A and B are not in the same path)

tox.ini.message:
Let's make it:

    py3, py2 (or py27), ...

to avoid making it work only for py37. This will enable the local running of tox jobs smoothly as earlier in anybody's dev/test env.

I think that in my local env if I have only py35 I can have the test cases run locally and can also see those running correctly in the gate jobs for py36/py37, and get feedback about it if anything is amiss in that env. As a developer, I may have the constraint of not moving to py37 just as now (possibly eventually have to). Others who are on py37 can still have their py37 jobs run if it's just provided `py3`.

The problem with the generic py3 is that a developer may be running py34 locally and py36/py37 in the gate which is much different. Most teams are switching to py37 only in the default tox envlist so as to save cycles vs running py36 and py37. With that said teams can do what they wish with the default envlist. Note that this is just what's run by default for 'tox'.
@Debayan, are you still -1 on the code review? Just let me know please so we can move forward with a solution. Thanks.
